metadata.description: Synthetic interventional pulmonology procedure notes with registry, CPT, and RVU data

thermal_ablation.note_text:
PATIENT: Robert Martinez, 72-year-old Male
MRN: 5589234
DOB: 04/22/1953
Date of Service: 12/05/2025
Location: Memorial Regional Medical Center, Phoenix, AZ

ATTENDING: Dr. Jennifer Walsh, MD - Interventional Pulmonology
FELLOW: Dr. Marcus Thompson, MD (PGY-6)

INDICATION: 72-year-old male with biopsy-proven squamous cell carcinoma of the right lower lobe, 2.4cm peripheral nodule in the superior segment (RB6). Patient is not a surgical candidate due to severe COPD (FEV1 0.9L, 32% predicted). PET SUV 8.2. Referred for bronchoscopic thermal ablation.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Right lower lobe squamous cell carcinoma, peripheral
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Bronchoscopy with electromagnetic navigation, radial EBUS confirmation, and microwave ablation of RLL nodule

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (8.0 ETT)
MONITORING: Standard ASA monitors, arterial line

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
After timeout and induction of general anesthesia, flexible bronchoscopy was performed through the ETT. Airways were inspected and found to be patent without endobronchial lesions. 

Electromagnetic navigation (superDimension system) was utilized to navigate to the RB6 segment. Registration error: 2.8mm. Target reached notification confirmed.

Radial EBUS (1.4mm probe) was advanced through the extended working channel. Concentric view obtained confirming tool-in-lesion position. Lesion measured 23mm on radial EBUS.

Cone-beam CT was performed confirming catheter tip within the lesion with adequate margins.

Microwave ablation probe (Neuwave Emprint, 15cm, 2.0cm antenna) was advanced to the target. Ablation performed:
- Power: 100W
- Duration: 10 minutes
- Target temperature achieved: 180°C
- Ablation zone confirmed on post-ablation CBCT: 3.2cm sphere

Post-ablation inspection showed no bleeding or airway injury. The patient was extubated without difficulty.

SPECIMENS: None (ablation only, prior biopsy confirmed diagnosis)

COMPLICATIONS: None
EBL: Minimal (<5mL)

IMPRESSION: Successful microwave ablation of 2.4cm RLL squamous cell carcinoma. Adequate ablation zone achieved with margins.

PLAN:
- Post-procedure CXR: No pneumothorax
- Admit for overnight observation
- CT chest in 1 month for treatment response
- Tumor board discussion for any additional therapy
- Follow-up in IP clinic 2 weeks

Dr. Jennifer Walsh, MD
Attending Interventional Pulmonologist

clinical_context.primary_indication: RLL squamous cell carcinoma, not surgical candidate

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tumor (microwave ablation) - primary therapeutic code.
code_rationales.31627: Navigation add-on for peripheral target guidance.
code_rationales.31654: Radial EBUS add-on for peripheral lesion confirmation.

coding_review.coding_rationale: Correctly coded for navigated microwave ablation. 31622 (diagnostic) is bundled. Add-on codes 31627 and 31654 are supported.

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tumor via microwave ablation - primary therapeutic code for thermal ablation of lung tumor
code_rationales.31627: Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy add-on for computer-assisted navigation to peripheral target
code_rationales.31654: Radial EBUS add-on for peripheral lesion localization and confirmation of tool-in-lesion

thermal_ablation.note_text:
Pt: Susan Chen || MRN: 7723401 || DOB: 11/08/1968
Date: 12/07/2025 || Location: University Hospital, San Diego, CA
MD: Dr. David Park, Interventional Pulmonology

Dx: Recurrent endobronchial carcinoid tumor, RML bronchus with 70% obstruction
Procedure: Rigid bronchoscopy with electrocautery ablation and tumor debulking

Under GA with rigid bronchoscopy (Karl Storz 12mm), inspection showed polypoid tumor arising from RML orifice causing significant obstruction. Normal mucosa proximal and distal to lesion.

Electrocautery (ERBE VIO 300D, 40W coag mode) applied to tumor base. Sequential application x 4 with excellent hemostasis. Tumor bulk reduced using rigid forceps debridement. Repeated electrocautery for remaining tumor tissue.

Post-ablation: RML bronchus now patent with <10% residual obstruction. Excellent airway patency restored. Minor oozing controlled with additional electrocautery touch-up.

No stent required. Flexible bronchoscopy through rigid barrel confirmed patent airways bilaterally. Therapeutic aspiration of secretions from RML.

Complications: None
EBL: 25mL

Impressions: Successful electrocautery ablation and debulking of recurrent RML carcinoid tumor. Airway patency restored.

Plan: 
- Observation 4 hours post-procedure
- CXR before discharge
- Follow-up bronchoscopy in 6 weeks
- Oncology follow-up for possible adjuvant therapy

D. Park, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Recurrent endobronchial carcinoid tumor with airway obstruction

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tumor (electrocautery/forceps) - dominant code for combined destruction and debulking at the same site.

coding_review.coding_rationale: Dropped 31640 (excision) because it was performed at the same anatomic site (RML) as the ablation (31641). Per coding rules, report only the higher-valued 31641 when both are performed on the same lesion.

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tumor via electrocautery - thermal ablation component
code_rationales.31640: Bronchoscopy with excision of tumor - mechanical debulking with rigid forceps at same site (reportable with -59 if distinct work documented)

rvu_summary_2025.bundling_note: 31641 and 31640 at same site may be bundled per NCCI; dominant code is 31641. Use -59 modifier on 31640 only if distinct excision work documented.

thermal_ablation.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: James O'Brien
MRN: 8834567
DOB: 07/14/1951 (74 years old)
Date of Procedure: 12/08/2025
Procedure Time: 09:15 - 11:45

Attending: Dr. Lisa Hernandez, MD
Fellow: Dr. Kevin Nguyen, MD (PGY-5)
Anesthesia: Dr. Robert Kim, MD

Indication: 74-year-old male with metastatic renal cell carcinoma to the left mainstem bronchus causing symptomatic airway obstruction (dyspnea, stridor). CT shows near-complete obstruction of LMS. Palliative debulking requested.

Preoperative Diagnosis: Metastatic RCC with LMS bronchus obstruction
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same

Procedures:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy
2. Argon plasma coagulation (APC) of endobronchial tumor
3. Mechanical debulking
4. Balloon dilation of LMS stenosis
5. Therapeutic aspiration

Anesthesia: General anesthesia, jet ventilation through rigid bronchoscope

Procedure Details:
After induction and timeout, rigid bronchoscope (Efer-Dumon 13.5mm) inserted. Inspection revealed hemorrhagic, friable tumor mass nearly occluding the LMS bronchus with approximately 90% obstruction. Tumor extended from 1cm below the main carina to the LUL takeoff.

APC (ERBE VIO, 60W, Flow 2.0 L/min) applied in pulsed mode to devascularize tumor surface. Excellent coagulation achieved with reduced bleeding during subsequent debulking.

Mechanical debulking performed using rigid coring technique and large biopsy forceps. Substantial tumor volume removed. Multiple specimens sent for pathology confirmation.

After tumor removal, residual stenosis noted. Balloon dilation (CRE 15-18mm) performed at 8 ATM x 60 seconds x 2 inflations. Good expansion achieved.

Therapeutic aspiration of copious post-obstructive secretions (~50mL purulent material).

Final inspection: LMS now 70% patent (post-obstruction reduced to 30%). LUL and LLL orifices visualized. Improved airflow noted.

Complications: Moderate bleeding controlled with APC
EBL: 75mL

Specimens: Endobronchial tumor tissue x 6 to surgical pathology

Post-Procedure:
- Stridor resolved
- SpO2 improved from 88% to 96% on 2L NC
- CXR: Improved LUL aeration, no pneumothorax
- Admit to stepdown for overnight monitoring

Plan:
- Repeat bronchoscopy in 4-6 weeks
- Palliative radiation oncology consult
- Continue supportive care

L. Hernandez, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Metastatic RCC with LMS bronchus obstruction

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tumor (APC/debulking) - primary therapeutic code covering excision, destruction, and dilation of the tumor.
code_rationales.31645: Therapeutic aspiration of 50mL post-obstructive purulent secretions - distinct therapeutic goal.

coding_review.coding_rationale: Dropped 31640 (excision) and 31630 (dilation) as they targeted the same tumor/site (LMS) as the APC ablation (31641). 31641 is the comprehensive code for tumor destruction/relief of stenosis. 31645 retained for significant purulent aspiration.

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tumor via APC - thermal ablation of endobronchial metastatic tumor
code_rationales.31640: Bronchoscopy with excision of tumor - mechanical debulking is distinct work from ablation (-59 modifier applies)
code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with dilation - balloon dilation of residual stenosis after tumor removal
code_rationales.31645: Bronchoscopy with therapeutic aspiration - removal of 50mL purulent post-obstructive secretions

whole_lung_lavage.note_text:
WHOLE LUNG LAVAGE PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Maria Gonzalez
MRN: 4456789
DOB: 03/25/1978 (47 years old)
Date of Procedure: 12/04/2025
Procedure Time: 07:00 - 12:30 (5.5 hours)
Location: University Medical Center OR Suite 4

Attending Pulmonologist: Dr. Michael Zhang, MD - Interventional Pulmonology
Attending Anesthesiologist: Dr. Sarah Williams, MD
Pulmonary Fellow: Dr. Amanda Foster, MD (PGY-5)
Respiratory Therapist: James Rodriguez, RRT
Circulating RN: Patricia Lee, RN

CLINICAL HISTORY:
47-year-old female with biopsy-proven pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) diagnosed 18 months ago. Anti-GM-CSF antibody positive (autoimmune PAP). Progressive dyspnea despite GM-CSF therapy. Current PFTs: FVC 2.1L (58% pred), DLCO 45% pred. 6MWT: 280m with desaturation to 82%. CT shows diffuse ground-glass opacities bilaterally with "crazy-paving" pattern. Referred for therapeutic whole lung lavage.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, autoimmune
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Whole Lung Lavage - Left lung

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube

PROCEDURE DETAILS:

Airway Management:
Patient brought to OR, standard monitors placed. Pre-oxygenation with 100% FiO2 x 5 minutes. Induction with propofol 150mg IV, fentanyl 100mcg IV, rocuronium 50mg IV. Direct laryngoscopy performed. Left-sided 37Fr double-lumen tube (Mallinckrodt) placed and position confirmed with fiberoptic bronchoscopy. Bronchial cuff in left mainstem, tracheal cuff above carina. Both lumens patent and functional.

Lung Isolation:
Left lung isolated. Lung separation confirmed by auscultation and bronchoscopy. Right lung ventilated with TV 400mL, RR 14, PEEP 5, FiO2 100%. SpO2 maintained 94-98% on single lung ventilation.

Lavage Procedure - Left Lung:
Warmed sterile normal saline (37°C) used for lavage. Aliquots of 1000mL instilled via gravity drainage through left bronchial lumen.

Lavage Summary:
- Total saline instilled: 18.5 liters
- Total fluid returned: 17.2 liters (93% return)
- Number of cycles: 18
- Initial effluent: Grossly milky/opaque
- Final effluent: Near-clear (cycle 16-18)
- Duration of lavage: 4 hours 15 minutes

Each cycle:
1. Instill 1000mL saline over 2-3 minutes
2. Allow 3-5 minute dwell time with gentle chest percussion
3. Drain by gravity and gentle suction
4. Monitor SpO2 (maintained >90% throughout)

Complications during lavage:
- Transient desaturation to 88% during cycle 12 (resolved with increased FiO2 and brief pause)
- No hemodynamic instability
- No saline spillover to ventilated lung

Post-Lavage:
Left lung recruitment performed with sustained inflation. Bronchoscopy confirmed clear airways bilaterally. DLT exchanged for single-lumen 7.5 ETT. Bilateral ventilation resumed.

ABG post-procedure: pH 7.38, pCO2 42, pO2 185 on 50% FiO2

COMPLICATIONS: None significant

SPECIMENS:
- Initial lavage fluid (cytology) - showing proteinaceous material
- Final lavage fluid (cytology) - for comparison

POST-PROCEDURE PLAN:
- Transfer to ICU intubated for overnight observation
- Wean ventilator as tolerated, goal extubation within 12-24 hours
- CXR 6 hours post-procedure
- Monitor for hypoxemia, fever
- Plan for right lung lavage in 2-4 weeks pending recovery
- Follow-up PFTs in 4-6 weeks

IMPRESSION:
Successful therapeutic whole lung lavage of left lung for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Good lavage return (93%) with clearing of effluent. Procedure tolerated well.

M. Zhang, MD
Interventional Pulmonology

clinical_context.primary_indication: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, autoimmune, refractory to medical therapy
clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities with crazy-paving pattern

code_rationales.32999: Unlisted procedure, lungs and pleura (Whole Lung Lavage).
code_rationales.31624: Bronchoscopy with BAL - distinct diagnostic component if supported, though often bundled into WLL.

coding_review.coding_rationale: WLL is unlisted (32999). 31624 retained as per original documentation for the BAL component, though payment for 32999 is carrier-priced.

code_rationales.31624: Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage - fiberoptic bronchoscopy performed for DLT positioning and post-lavage inspection
code_rationales.32999: Unlisted procedure, lungs and pleura - whole lung lavage has no specific CPT code; reported as unlisted with detailed operative note. Use -LT modifier for left side.

cpt_summary.coding_notes: Whole lung lavage (WLL) does not have a dedicated CPT code. It is typically reported using 32999 (unlisted thoracic procedure) with a detailed operative note. 31624 may be added if bronchoscopy with BAL is a distinct service. Some facilities report 31899 (unlisted bronchoscopy) instead. Reimbursement is carrier-dependent and often requires prior authorization.

32999.note: Unlisted codes are priced by comparison to similar procedures. WLL is often priced similar to thoracotomy-level work (15-25 RVUs).

whole_lung_lavage.note_text:
PROCEDURE NOTE - WHOLE LUNG LAVAGE

Patient: Thomas Wilson
MRN: 6678234
DOB: 09/12/1965 (60 years old)
Date: 12/06/2025
Location: Regional Pulmonary Center, Denver, CO

Procedure Team:
- Attending: Dr. Rebecca Stone, MD (IP)
- Anesthesiology: Dr. John Peters, MD
- RT: Carlos Mendez, RRT

Indication: 60-year-old male with secondary PAP in setting of occupational silica exposure (sandblaster x 25 years). Progressive hypoxemia, baseline SpO2 88% on 3L NC. Prior left WLL performed 6 months ago with good response. Now presenting with recurrent symptoms. Scheduled for right WLL.

Pre-procedure PFTs: FVC 2.5L (55%), FEV1 2.0L (52%), DLCO 38%
CT Chest: Diffuse ground-glass with superimposed silicotic nodules, right > left

Procedure: Whole Lung Lavage - Right Lung

Anesthesia: General with left-sided 39Fr DLT (patient is 6'1", 95kg)

Procedure Details:
DLT placed and position confirmed bronchoscopically. Left lung ventilation initiated. Right lung isolation confirmed.

Lavage performed with warmed saline (37°C):
- Aliquots: 1200mL (larger due to patient size)
- Total instilled: 22 liters
- Total returned: 20.3 liters (92.3%)
- Cycles: 20
- Initial return: Thick, tan-colored (silica-laden)
- Final return: Light hazy, significant improvement
- Duration: 5 hours

Notable events:
- Bronchospasm during cycle 8, treated with albuterol via ventilator circuit
- SpO2 nadir 86% briefly, recovered with increased PEEP
- Chest percussion performed by RT with each cycle

Post-lavage bronchoscopy: Airways clear, no residual debris. Mild mucosal erythema in RMS.

DLT exchanged to 8.0 single-lumen ETT. Extubated in OR after meeting criteria. Patient awake, following commands, SpO2 94% on 4L NC.

Complications: Transient bronchospasm (resolved)
Specimens: Lavage fluid samples x 2 sent to cytology

Disposition: PACU then step-down unit for 24-hour observation

Plan:
- Serial CXRs
- Supplemental O2 as needed
- Repeat PFTs in 4-6 weeks
- Occupational medicine follow-up
- Consider left lung re-lavage if symptoms recur

R. Stone, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Secondary PAP from occupational silicosis, recurrent symptoms after prior left WLL
clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Diffuse ground-glass with silicotic nodules, right > left

code_rationales.32999: Unlisted procedure, lungs and pleura (Whole Lung Lavage).

coding_review.coding_rationale: WLL is unlisted (32999). 31624 retained for BAL.

code_rationales.31624: Bronchoscopy with BAL - used for DLT positioning, tube confirmation, and post-lavage inspection
code_rationales.32999: Unlisted thoracic procedure for right whole lung lavage (no specific CPT exists). Use -RT modifier for right side.

whole_lung_lavage.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY
WHOLE LUNG LAVAGE - BILATERAL (SEQUENTIAL)

Patient Information:
Name: Jennifer Adams
MRN: 9912345
DOB: 06/30/1982 (43 years old)
Date of Procedure: 12/03/2025
Procedure Duration: 07:00 - 16:00 (9 hours total)

Care Team:
Attending IP: Dr. William Chen, MD
Attending Anesthesia: Dr. Nancy Brown, MD
IP Fellow: Dr. Sarah Kim, MD (PGY-6)
CRNA: Michael Torres, CRNA
RT Team: Jessica White, RRT; David Garcia, RRT

Clinical Summary:
43-year-old female with severe autoimmune PAP diagnosed 2 years ago, anti-GM-CSF antibody titer >1:1000. Failed inhaled GM-CSF therapy and rituximab. Severe hypoxemic respiratory failure with baseline SpO2 85% on 6L NC. Room air ABG: pH 7.44, pCO2 32, pO2 48. CT shows dense bilateral ground-glass with crazy-paving. Given severity, decision made for bilateral sequential WLL in single session.

Preoperative Diagnosis: Severe autoimmune PAP with respiratory failure
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same

Procedures:
1. Whole Lung Lavage - Right Lung
2. Whole Lung Lavage - Left Lung (sequential)
3. Bronchoscopy with inspection

Anesthesia: General anesthesia, right-sided 37Fr DLT (for initial left lung lavage), repositioned for right lung lavage

=== LEFT LUNG LAVAGE (First) ===
Time: 07:30 - 11:00
Volume instilled: 20 liters
Volume returned: 18.5 liters (92.5%)
Cycles: 20
Initial effluent: Thick, milky white
Final effluent: Slightly hazy
Complications: None

=== INTERMISSION ===
DLT repositioned to left-sided 37Fr for right lung lavage
Bilateral ventilation x 30 minutes
ABG check: pH 7.36, pCO2 44, pO2 165 on 100% FiO2
Patient hemodynamically stable

=== RIGHT LUNG LAVAGE (Second) ===
Time: 11:45 - 15:30
Volume instilled: 19 liters
Volume returned: 17.8 liters (93.7%)
Cycles: 19
Initial effluent: Thick, milky white (similar to left)
Final effluent: Nearly clear
Complications: None

=== POST-PROCEDURE ===
Final bronchoscopy: Both mainstems clear, no residual debris
DLT exchanged to 7.5 single-lumen ETT
Patient transported to ICU intubated
Post-procedure ABG: pH 7.40, pCO2 40, pO2 220 on 50% FiO2 (significantly improved)

Total Lavage Summary:
- Combined volume instilled: 39 liters
- Combined volume returned: 36.3 liters (93%)
- Total cycles: 39

Specimens: Initial and final lavage fluid from each lung sent to cytology

Complications: None

Disposition: ICU intubated, plan for extubation in 12-24 hours if stable

Plan:
- Mechanical ventilation with lung-protective settings
- Serial ABGs and CXRs
- Wean FiO2 as tolerated
- Goal extubation within 24 hours
- Repeat PFTs in 4-6 weeks
- Consider repeat lavage if incomplete response

W. Chen, MD
S. Kim, MD (Fellow)

clinical_context.primary_indication: Severe autoimmune PAP with hypoxemic respiratory failure, failed medical therapy
clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Dense bilateral ground-glass opacities with crazy-paving pattern

coding_review.coding_rationale: Bilateral sequential WLL reported with unlisted codes. RVUs by report.

code_rationales.31624: Bronchoscopy with BAL for DLT positioning and post-procedure airway inspection
code_rationales.32999-LT: Unlisted thoracic procedure - left whole lung lavage
code_rationales.32999-RT: Unlisted thoracic procedure - right whole lung lavage, sequential in same session

cpt_summary.coding_notes: Bilateral sequential WLL in same session should be reported with separate 32999 codes for each lung using anatomic modifiers (-LT, -RT). Some payers may require prior authorization for bilateral procedure. Documentation should clearly distinguish each lung's lavage as distinct procedure.

thoracentesis.note_text:
THORACENTESIS PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Robert Anderson
MRN: 3345678
DOB: 08/17/1958 (67 years old)
Date of Procedure: 12/08/2025
Time: 10:30 - 11:00
Location: Procedure Suite, University Hospital

Attending: Dr. Emily Morrison, MD - Pulmonary/Critical Care
Fellow: Dr. Jason Park, MD (PGY-6)

Indication:
67-year-old male with newly diagnosed stage IV non-small cell lung cancer (adenocarcinoma, EGFR+) presenting with progressive dyspnea and large right-sided pleural effusion on CT chest. Thoracentesis for diagnostic workup and symptomatic relief.

Pre-Procedure:
- Informed consent obtained; risks discussed including pneumothorax, bleeding, infection, re-expansion pulmonary edema
- Timeout performed
- Coagulation: INR 1.1, Platelets 189K - no contraindication to procedure
- Bedside ultrasound: Large right pleural effusion, maximum depth 7.8cm, no septations, no lung sliding at effusion site
- Vital signs: BP 142/88, HR 78, SpO2 94% on 2L NC

Procedure Details:
- Patient positioned sitting upright, leaning forward on bedside table
- Right posterior chest wall, 8th intercostal space, posterior axillary line selected
- Skin prepped with chlorhexidine, sterile drape applied
- Local anesthesia: 10mL 1% lidocaine with epinephrine infiltrated to skin, subcutaneous tissue, and parietal pleura
- Real-time ultrasound guidance used throughout
- 18-gauge catheter-over-needle system inserted perpendicular to chest wall
- Pleural space entered, clear straw-colored fluid obtained
- Catheter advanced, needle withdrawn
- Three-way stopcock and drainage tubing connected
- Total volume removed: 1,500mL (stopped per protocol to minimize re-expansion risk)
- Fluid appearance: Clear, straw-colored, no turbidity
- Post-procedure ultrasound: Residual effusion present (~3cm depth), lung sliding present, no pneumothorax

Pleural Fluid Studies Sent:
- Cell count with differential
- Protein, LDH, glucose, pH
- Cytology (2 specimens)
- Bacterial, fungal, AFB cultures
- Adenosine deaminase
- Tumor markers (CEA)

Immediate Results:
- Appearance: Serous, straw-colored
- Likely exudative (clinical suspicion for malignancy)

Post-Procedure:
- Patient tolerated procedure well, no chest pain or dyspnea
- Portable CXR obtained: Decreased right effusion, no pneumothorax
- Vital signs stable: BP 138/82, HR 76, SpO2 97% on room air
- Dyspnea significantly improved

Complications: None

Assessment:
Diagnostic and therapeutic thoracentesis of right malignant-appearing pleural effusion. 1.5L removed with symptomatic improvement.

Plan:
- Await cytology results
- If positive for malignancy, refer for tunneled pleural catheter placement
- Follow-up in pulmonary clinic in 1 week
- Continue supplemental O2 PRN

E. Morrison, MD
J. Park, MD (Fellow)

clinical_context.primary_indication: Large right pleural effusion, suspected malignant, symptomatic dyspnea

coding_review.coding_rationale: Correctly coded. Imaging guidance 76942 is bundled.

code_rationales.32555: Thoracentesis, needle or catheter, aspiration of pleural space; with imaging guidance. Real-time ultrasound guidance was used for needle placement. Imaging guidance (76942) is bundled and not separately reported.

rvu_summary_2025.bundling_note: Post-procedure CXR (71045/71046) for pneumothorax check is bundled per NCCI and not separately reportable.

thoracentesis.note_text:
PROCEDURE NOTE - BEDSIDE THORACENTESIS

Patient: Linda Martinez
MRN: 4478901
DOB: 12/03/1970 (55 years old)
Date: 12/07/2025
Time: 14:15 - 14:35
Location: Medical ICU, Bed 12

Attending: Dr. Christopher Lee, MD - Critical Care

Indication:
55-year-old female with decompensated cirrhosis (Child-Pugh C), hepatorenal syndrome, and new left-sided pleural effusion causing respiratory distress. Large volume paracentesis performed earlier today. Thoracentesis for diagnostic workup to rule out infection (SBP equivalent) vs hepatic hydrothorax vs malignancy.

Pre-Procedure:
- Consent obtained from healthcare proxy (patient intubated/sedated)
- Coagulation: INR 1.8, Platelets 67K - thrombocytopenia noted but clinically indicated procedure
- FFP 2 units given prior to procedure per ICU protocol
- Post-transfusion INR: 1.4
- Bedside US: Moderate left effusion, ~4cm depth, simple appearing

Procedure:
- Patient in right lateral decubitus position (left side up)
- Left posterior-lateral chest wall, 7th intercostal space
- Chlorhexidine prep, sterile drape
- Local: 8mL 1% lidocaine
- Ultrasound-guided 18G catheter insertion
- Clear, transudative-appearing fluid obtained
- Volume removed: 650mL (limited due to effusion size and patient tolerance)
- Fluid: Clear, pale yellow
- Post-procedure US: Minimal residual effusion, lung sliding present

Fluid Studies:
- Cell count (WBC 180/uL, 12% PMN - reassuring for SBP equivalent)
- Chemistry (protein, LDH, albumin for Light's criteria)
- Gram stain, culture
- Triglycerides (r/o chylothorax)

Complications: None. Patient remained hemodynamically stable on vasopressors throughout.

Post-Procedure:
- CXR: Small residual effusion, no PTX
- Respiratory status unchanged on current ventilator settings

Impression: Diagnostic thoracentesis of left pleural effusion in setting of decompensated cirrhosis. Fluid appears transudative, low PMN count reassuring against infection.

Plan:
- Await final culture results
- If hepatic hydrothorax confirmed, optimize diuresis
- Hepatology consulted for transplant evaluation

C. Lee, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Left pleural effusion in decompensated cirrhosis, r/o infection

code_rationales.32555: Thoracentesis with imaging guidance - ultrasound used for real-time needle guidance on left side.

thoracentesis.note_text:
THORACENTESIS PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: David Kim
MRN: 5567234
DOB: 02/28/1952 (73 years old)
Date: 12/05/2025
Time: 09:00 - 09:25
Location: Outpatient Procedure Center

Physician: Dr. Amanda White, MD - Pulmonology

Indication:
73-year-old male with history of CHF (EF 30%), presenting with worsening bilateral lower extremity edema and dyspnea. CXR shows bilateral pleural effusions, right > left. BNP elevated at 2,400. Thoracentesis for diagnostic purposes to differentiate transudative (CHF) vs exudative effusion and for symptomatic relief.

Pre-Procedure Assessment:
- Consent obtained, risks/benefits discussed
- No anticoagulation (held warfarin 5 days ago, bridged with enoxaparin, last dose >24 hours ago)
- INR: 1.3, Platelets: 245K
- Ultrasound: Right pleural effusion, 6.2cm depth, anechoic, no loculations
- Vitals: BP 158/92, HR 88 (irregular - AFib), SpO2 91% on RA

Procedure:
- Patient seated, leaning forward
- Right posterolateral chest, 9th intercostal space, scapular line
- Skin prep with chlorhexidine, sterile field
- Local anesthesia: 12mL 1% lidocaine
- Ultrasound-guided catheter placement using Safe-T-Centesis kit
- Straw-colored, clear fluid obtained immediately
- Drainage via vacuum bottles
- Volume removed: 1,800mL
- Stopped as patient reported mild chest tightness (likely pleural stretch)
- Final fluid: Clear throughout, no blood-tinged
- Post-procedure US: Lung sliding present, small residual effusion (~1.5cm)

Specimens Sent:
- Pleural fluid chemistry: Protein 2.1, LDH 98 (serum: Protein 6.8, LDH 180)
- Cell count: WBC 120, 85% lymphocytes
- Cytology x 1
- pH: 7.48

Preliminary Interpretation:
Light's criteria suggest transudative effusion:
- Pleural protein/serum protein = 0.31 (<0.5)
- Pleural LDH/serum LDH = 0.54 (<0.6)
- Pleural LDH = 98 (<2/3 upper limit normal = 120)
Consistent with CHF-related effusion.

Complications: None. Mild chest tightness resolved after stopping drainage.

Post-Procedure:
- CXR: Significantly decreased right effusion, no pneumothorax, improved aeration
- SpO2: 96% on RA (improved from 91%)
- Patient feels much better, dyspnea improved

Disposition: Home with outpatient follow-up

Plan:
- Optimize heart failure management (diuretics increased)
- Cardiology follow-up
- If effusion recurs rapidly despite diuresis, consider repeat thoracentesis or PleurX
- Return if worsening dyspnea

A. White, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Bilateral pleural effusions in CHF, diagnostic and therapeutic thoracentesis

code_rationales.32555: Thoracentesis with ultrasound imaging guidance. Code includes both diagnostic and therapeutic aspects when performed at same session. Imaging guidance (76942) is bundled.

foreign_body_removal.note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY PROCEDURE NOTE - FOREIGN BODY REMOVAL

Patient: Tommy Rodriguez
MRN: 6654321
DOB: 03/15/2021 (4 years old)
Date of Procedure: 12/08/2025
Time: Emergency procedure, 22:30 - 23:15
Location: Pediatric OR, Children's Hospital

Attending: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD - Pediatric Pulmonology
Pediatric Anesthesia: Dr. Michael Brown, MD
Pediatric Surgery (standby): Dr. Elizabeth Wong, MD

Clinical Presentation:
4-year-old male brought to ED by parents after witnessed aspiration of a peanut approximately 3 hours ago while eating. Presented with persistent cough, mild respiratory distress, and unilateral wheezing on right side. Chest X-ray shows hyperinflation of right lung with air trapping. No complete obstruction. Vitals stable but tachypneic (RR 32).

Preoperative Diagnosis: Foreign body aspiration (peanut), right bronchus
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same

Procedure: Rigid bronchoscopy with foreign body removal

Anesthesia: General anesthesia with spontaneous ventilation initially, then controlled ventilation through rigid bronchoscope

Procedure Details:
After induction with sevoflurane, patient maintained on spontaneous ventilation initially. Rigid bronchoscope (Karl Storz 3.5mm pediatric) introduced through oral cavity.

Findings:
- Vocal cords normal, no edema
- Subglottic area clear
- Trachea: Mild secretions, suctioned
- Main carina: Normal
- Left mainstem: Patent, no abnormalities
- Right mainstem: FOREIGN BODY IDENTIFIED - peanut fragment lodged at bronchus intermedius takeoff

Foreign body appeared to be fragmenting with surrounding granulation tissue/mucus. Careful extraction performed.

Removal Technique:
1. Optical forceps (alligator-type) used to grasp peanut fragment
2. Initial attempt resulted in partial fragmentation
3. Basket retrieval device deployed to capture remaining fragments
4. Three passes required for complete removal
5. All visible fragments retrieved

Materials Retrieved:
- One main peanut fragment (~8mm)
- Multiple smaller fragments
- Total estimated: Complete peanut half

Post-Removal Inspection:
- Bronchus intermedius: Mild mucosal edema and erythema, no residual foreign material
- RML and RLL orifices visualized, patent
- Therapeutic aspiration of thick secretions from right lower lobe
- No bleeding

Patient extubated in OR, transferred to PACU in stable condition.

Complications: None
EBL: Minimal

Specimens: Foreign body (peanut fragments) - discarded per protocol, photographed for documentation

Post-Procedure:
- Dexamethasone 4mg IV given for airway edema prophylaxis
- CXR: Resolution of right lung hyperinflation, no pneumothorax
- SpO2 98% on RA
- Cough improved

Disposition: Admit for overnight observation per protocol

Plan:
- NPO overnight, advance diet in AM if stable
- Albuterol nebs PRN
- Repeat CXR in AM
- If stable, discharge home with pediatrician follow-up
- Parents counseled on choking hazards and avoidance of peanuts in young children

S. Chen, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Foreign body aspiration (peanut), witnessed event, respiratory distress

code_rationales.31635: Bronchoscopy with removal of foreign body.

coding_review.coding_rationale: Correctly coded for rigid bronchoscopy FB removal.

code_rationales.31635: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible, with removal of foreign body. Includes all work related to foreign body extraction including visualization, instrumentation, and removal. Therapeutic aspiration at same session is bundled.

foreign_body_removal.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Harold Thompson
MRN: 7765432
DOB: 07/22/1949 (76 years old)
Date: 12/06/2025
Time: 14:00 - 15:30
Location: Bronchoscopy Suite, VA Medical Center

Attending: Dr. James Wilson, MD - Interventional Pulmonology
Fellow: Dr. Michelle Garcia, MD (PGY-6)
Anesthesia: MAC with Dr. Robert Taylor, MD

Clinical History:
76-year-old male with history of laryngeal cancer s/p total laryngectomy and permanent tracheostomy (2018), recurrent aspiration. Patient presented with 2-week history of worsening cough and recurrent pneumonia. CT chest showed RML consolidation with possible foreign body. Patient reports he may have accidentally aspirated a piece of his tracheostomy cleaning brush approximately 2 weeks ago.

Preoperative Diagnosis: Suspected airway foreign body (tracheostomy brush component)
Postoperative Diagnosis: Confirmed - plastic foreign body in right middle lobe bronchus

Procedure: 
1. Flexible bronchoscopy through tracheostomy
2. Removal of airway foreign body
3. Therapeutic aspiration

Anesthesia: Moderate sedation (MAC) with fentanyl, midazolam, and propofol infusion. Supplemental O2 via tracheostomy collar during procedure.

Procedure Details:
Flexible bronchoscope (Olympus BF-1TH190) introduced through established tracheostomy stoma.

Findings:
- Trachea: Mild secretions, granulation tissue at stoma site (chronic, stable)
- Main carina: Normal
- Left lung: Clear airways
- Right mainstem: Increased secretions
- RUL: Patent
- Bronchus intermedius: Moderate purulent secretions
- RML orifice: FOREIGN BODY IDENTIFIED - blue plastic brush bristle tip impacted in medial segment, approximately 2cm length visible

Removal Technique:
Due to impacted nature and inflammatory response:
1. Copious secretions suctioned from RML
2. Cryoprobe (1.9mm) applied to foreign body with 3-second freeze
3. Foreign body adherent to cryoprobe, extracted en bloc with single pass
4. Complete removal confirmed

Foreign Body Description:
- Blue plastic brush bristle cluster, approximately 3cm total length
- Consistent with tracheostomy cleaning brush component
- Documented with photograph

Post-Removal:
- RML mucosa: Edematous with contact bleeding, controlled with cold saline lavage
- Purulent secretions aspirated from RML (sent for culture)
- RLL: Patent, minimal secretions
- No residual foreign material

Complications: Minor contact bleeding (resolved)
EBL: 10mL

Specimens:
- Foreign body: Saved per patient request
- RML secretions: Culture

Post-Procedure:
- Patient tolerated procedure well, no respiratory distress
- Tracheostomy functioning normally
- CXR: Stable, RML infiltrate still present (expected)

Disposition: Outpatient discharge

Plan:
- Complete antibiotic course (levofloxacin 750mg daily x 5 more days)
- Follow-up CXR in 2 weeks
- Return to clinic in 3 weeks
- Reinforce tracheostomy care education, recommend replacement of cleaning supplies
- Continue routine tracheostomy care

J. Wilson, MD
M. Garcia, MD (Fellow)

clinical_context.primary_indication: Suspected foreign body aspiration (tracheostomy brush component) with recurrent pneumonia

code_rationales.31635: Bronchoscopy with removal of foreign body - performed through tracheostomy.

coding_review.coding_rationale: Dropped 31615 (tracheobronchoscopy). When a therapeutic bronchoscopy (31635) is performed through a tracheostomy, the approach code 31615 is bundled.

code_rationales.31635: Bronchoscopy with removal of foreign body - primary procedure code for extraction of plastic brush component from RML using cryoprobe technique
code_rationales.31615: Tracheobronchoscopy through established tracheostomy - used when bronchoscopy is performed through a tracheostomy rather than oronasally. May be separately reportable from 31635.

cpt_summary.coding_notes: When bronchoscopy is performed through an established tracheostomy, 31615 may be reported in addition to the therapeutic bronchoscopy code. Some payers may bundle these; check local coverage determinations.

foreign_body_removal.note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY FOR FOREIGN BODY REMOVAL

Patient: Margaret O'Connor
MRN: 8876543
DOB: 11/05/1958 (67 years old)
Date: 12/04/2025
Procedure Time: 10:00 - 11:45
Location: Operating Room 3, Memorial Hospital

Attending IP: Dr. Richard Martinez, MD
Anesthesia: Dr. Laura Kim, MD
OR Staff: RN Kelly Smith, ST John Davis

History:
67-year-old female with history of dysphagia secondary to stroke (2023), aspiration risk. Two days ago, patient aspirated a dental crown during a choking episode while eating. Chest CT shows metallic density in left lower lobe basilar segment. Patient with persistent cough, low-grade fever, and left-sided chest discomfort.

Preoperative Diagnosis: Left lower lobe foreign body (dental crown)
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same - confirmed metallic dental crown

Procedures Performed:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy
2. Flexible bronchoscopy
3. Foreign body removal with multiple techniques
4. Balloon dilation of LLL segmental bronchus

Anesthesia: General endotracheal anesthesia (7.5 ETT initially, then exchanged for rigid)

Procedure In Detail:

Initial flexible bronchoscopy performed showing extensive mucopurulent secretions in LLL with visible metallic foreign body impacted in LB10 (posterior basal segment). Mucosal edema and granulation tissue noted around foreign body. Decision made to convert to rigid bronchoscopy given impacted nature.

ETT exchanged for rigid bronchoscope (Efer-Dumon 11mm). Foreign body visualized - gold-colored dental crown, approximately 12mm diameter, wedged tightly in LB10.

Removal Attempts:
1. Rigid optical forceps - grasped crown but slipped due to smooth surface and impaction
2. Dormia basket - unable to deploy past crown due to tight impaction
3. Cryoprobe technique - limited adhesion to metallic surface, unsuccessful
4. Snare device deployed - successfully looped around crown margin
5. Gentle traction with snare + counter-pressure with rigid barrel
6. Crown extracted en bloc after 20 minutes of manipulation

Foreign Body Retrieved:
- Dental crown (porcelain-fused-to-metal)
- Size: 12mm x 10mm
- Intact, no fragments identified

Post-Extraction:
- Significant mucosal edema at impaction site with 60% narrowing of LB10
- Balloon dilation (CRE 8-10mm) performed at 6 ATM x 2 minutes
- Post-dilation: 80% luminal patency restored
- Purulent secretions suctioned from LLL
- BAL performed (30mL saline, sent for culture)
- Hemostasis achieved with cold saline

Final inspection via flexible bronchoscopy: All airways patent, no residual foreign body, minimal bleeding.

Complications: Moderate mucosal bleeding (controlled), prolonged procedure time
EBL: 50mL

Specimens:
- Foreign body: Returned to patient in labeled container
- BAL: Bacterial, fungal, AFB cultures

Post-Procedure:
- Patient extubated without difficulty
- CXR: LLL infiltrate (aspiration pneumonia), no PTX
- SpO2 95% on 2L NC
- Voice intact (no vocal cord injury)

Disposition: Admission for 24-48 hours for IV antibiotics and monitoring

Plan:
- IV ampicillin-sulbactam for aspiration pneumonia
- Speech therapy consult for dysphagia evaluation before advancing diet
- Repeat CXR in 24 hours
- Dental consultation for crown replacement and oral health
- Neurology follow-up for stroke/dysphagia management
- Follow-up bronchoscopy in 6 weeks if persistent symptoms

R. Martinez, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Aspirated dental crown with aspiration pneumonia, dysphagia from prior stroke

foreign_body_removal.location: Left lower lobe, posterior basal segment (LB10)

code_rationales.31635: Bronchoscopy with removal of foreign body.
code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with dilation - performed to treat post-extraction stenosis, distinct from extraction itself.

coding_review.coding_rationale: Retained 31630 with modifier -59 as documentation supports dilation as a distinct therapeutic service for post-extraction stenosis/edema, separate from the removal itself.

modifiers: -59 on 31630 if distinct anatomic work documented

code_rationales.31635: Bronchoscopy with removal of foreign body - primary code for extraction of dental crown from LB10
code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with dilation of airway - balloon dilation of post-extraction stenosis in LB10. Reportable as distinct service since dilation was performed to treat mucosal edema/stenosis after foreign body extraction, not as part of the extraction itself.

cpt_summary.coding_notes: 31630 for dilation is typically bundled with 31635 when dilation is performed solely to facilitate foreign body extraction. However, when dilation is performed to treat post-extraction stenosis as a separate therapeutic goal, it may be separately reportable with modifier -59.

rvu_summary_2025.bundling_note: Per NCCI, 31630 may be bundled with 31635 unless distinct anatomic site or separate therapeutic goal is documented. Use -59/-XS modifier when appropriate.
